Question Text: Do you maintain liaisons and points of contact with local authorities in accordance with contracts and appropriate regulations?
Comment: Our Incident Response and Business Continuity Policy includes procedures for coordinating with law enforcement and regulatory authorities when required. While we maintain the capability to establish appropriate contacts as needed, formal liaison relationships are established on a case-by-case basis given our organizational size.

Question Text: Do you have a documented security incident response plan?
Comment: IBP maintains a comprehensive Incident Response and Business Continuity Policy with detailed incident response procedures, classification matrix, response timelines, and clearly defined team roles including Incident Commander, Technical Lead, and Communications responsibilities.

Question Text: Do you integrate customized tenant requirements into your security incident response plans?\n\nWill Bayer be notified within 24 hours of a confirmed incident/breach?
Comment: Our Incident Response Policy establishes customer communication protocols with notification timelines. We commit to rapid notification for confirmed security incidents affecting customer data, with the specific goal of 24-hour notification for critical incidents, though this would be formalized in customer service agreements.

Question Text: Do you publish a roles and responsibilities document specifying what you vs. your tenants are responsible for during security incidents?
Comment: IBP follows the AWS shared responsibility model as documented in our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. Our policies clearly define IBP responsibilities versus customer responsibilities, though we would develop customer-specific responsibility matrices as part of formal service agreements.

Question Text: Have you tested your security incident response plans in the last year?
Comment: Our Incident Response Policy mandates regular testing including quarterly tabletop exercises and annual disaster recovery testing. We conduct scenario-based exercises and system recovery tests with documented results and improvement actions.

Question Text: Are workforce personnel and external business relationships adequately informed of their responsibility, and, if required, consent and/or contractually required to report all information security events in a timely manner?\n\nPlease describe your SIEM solution and what events are logged and monitored. Are alerts generated when certain thresholds are reached (e.g., changes to audit records (1), unauthorized elevation of privileges (1), take over ownership (1), failed logins (5))?
Comment: Our Remote Work Security Policy establishes incident reporting obligations for all personnel. We utilize AWS-native monitoring including CloudWatch, GuardDuty for threat detection, and CloudTrail for API logging. Basic alerting is configured for security events, though comprehensive SIEM capabilities would be enhanced for enterprise customers like Bayer.

Question Text: Do you have predefined communication channels for workforce personnel and external business partners to report incidents in a timely manner adhering to applicable legal, statutory, or regulatory compliance obligations?
Comment: Our Incident Response Policy defines multiple communication channels including Slack, email, and phone for incident reporting. Our GDPR compliance framework includes breach notification procedures, with established templates and notification processes for regulatory requirements.

Question Text: Does your incident response plan comply with industry standards for legally admissible chain-of-custody management processes and controls?
Comment: Our Incident Response Policy incorporates evidence preservation procedures and legal coordination protocols. While we maintain documented evidence collection procedures, we would engage specialized legal and forensic expertise for complex investigations requiring formal chain-of-custody management.

Question Text: Does your incident response capability include the use of legally admissible forensic data collection and analysis techniques?
Comment: While our incident response procedures include evidence collection using AWS logging tools and we maintain audit trails, we do not currently have in-house forensic analysis capabilities. For incidents requiring formal forensic investigation, we would engage qualified external forensic experts to ensure legally admissible evidence handling.

Question Text: Are you capable of supporting litigation holds (freeze of data from a specific point in time) for a specific tenant without freezing other tenant data?
Comment: Our Data Protection Policy establishes tenant data segregation controls and AWS backup capabilities enable point-in-time data preservation. We can implement customer-specific data preservation through backup systems and versioning controls without affecting other customers' operations.

Question Text: Do you enforce and attest to tenant data separation when producing data in response to legal subpoenas?
Comment: Our Access Control Policy establishes comprehensive tenant data segregation using database-level controls, resource tagging, and encryption key separation. Our data architecture enables precise data extraction for legal requests while maintaining strict tenant separation through technical controls.

Question Text: Do you monitor and quantify the types, volumes, and impacts on all information security incidents?
Comment: Our Incident Response Policy establishes incident metrics and classification systems. We maintain incident tracking with basic metrics collection, though comprehensive quantitative analysis capabilities would be expanded for enterprise customer requirements.

Question Text: Will you share statistical information for security incident data with your tenants upon request?\n\nNote - This is specifically referring to only incidents that may directly impact/relate to Bayer
Comment: Our Incident Response Policy supports transparent customer communication. We can provide Bayer with incident statistics relevant to their services, though comprehensive statistical reporting capabilities would be developed as part of formal service agreements.

Question Text: Do you inspect and account for data quality errors and associated risks, and work with your cloud supply-chain partners to correct them?
Comment: Our Data Protection Policy establishes data quality management procedures including validation controls and quality assessments. We work with AWS through standard support channels for service quality issues and maintain data quality monitoring within our applications.

Question Text: Do you design and implement controls to mitigate and contain data security risks through proper separation of duties, role-based access, and least-privileged access for all personnel within your supply chain?\n\nHow do you address security with your hosting provider and any other providers?
Comment: Our Access Control Policy implements role-based access controls with least-privilege principles, and our Vendor Management Policy establishes security requirements for third-party providers including AWS. We maintain vendor security assessments and contractual security obligations for all critical suppliers.

Question Text: Do you make security incident information available to all affected customers and providers periodically through electronic methods (e.g., portals)?
Comment: While our Incident Response Policy establishes customer communication protocols, we do not currently maintain a customer portal for incident information. We provide incident information through direct communication channels (email, phone) and would develop portal capabilities if required for enterprise customers like Bayer.

Question Text: Do you collect capacity and use data for all relevant components of your cloud service offering?
Comment: Our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy includes capacity planning procedures, and we utilize AWS CloudWatch for monitoring system performance and resource utilization across our infrastructure components with automated scaling capabilities.

Question Text: Do you provide tenants with capacity planning and use reports?
Comment: While we maintain capacity monitoring capabilities through AWS CloudWatch, we do not currently provide formal capacity planning reports to customers. This capability would be developed as part of enterprise service agreements and could be implemented for Bayer's requirements.

Question Text: Do you perform annual internal assessments of conformance and effectiveness of your policies, procedures, and supporting measures and metrics?
Comment: Our Compliance and Audit Management Policy mandates annual internal security assessments including policy effectiveness reviews and control validation. We conduct regular policy reviews and maintain improvement processes based on assessment results.

Question Text: Do you select and monitor outsourced providers in compliance with laws in the country where the data is processed, stored, and transmitted?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy establishes vendor selection criteria including regulatory compliance verification and geographic requirements. We maintain compliance documentation for all outsourced providers processing customer data, with particular attention to GDPR requirements.

Question Text: Do you select and monitor outsourced providers to ensure that they are in compliance with applicable legislation?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy requires compliance verification for all critical vendors through regular assessments, certification reviews, and contractual compliance obligations with documented vendor performance tracking.

Question Text: Does legal counsel review all third-party agreements?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy requires legal review for significant vendor agreements. Given our organizational size, we engage external legal counsel for contract reviews including security terms and compliance obligations for material agreements.

Question Text: Do third-party agreements include provision for the security and protection of information and assets?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy mandates comprehensive security clauses in vendor contracts including data protection agreements, encryption requirements, access controls, and security compliance obligations appropriate to the risk level.

Question Text: Do you have the capability to recover data for a specific customer in the case of a failure or data loss?
Comment: Our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy establishes comprehensive backup procedures including automated daily backups, cross-region replication, and point-in-time recovery capabilities. We maintain customer-specific backup isolation enabling individual customer data recovery.

Question Text: Do you have the capability to restrict the storage of customer data to specific countries or geographic locations?\n\nWhere will Bayer data be stored?
Comment: Our Data Protection Policy addresses data residency controls using AWS regional services. For Bayer, data would be stored in AWS EU regions to ensure GDPR compliance and European data residency. We can accommodate specific geographic restrictions through AWS regional deployment options.

Question Text: Can you provide the physical location/geography of storage of a tenant's data upon request?\n\nWhere is the data physically located? Has that been determined yet?
Comment: IBP utilizes AWS EU regions for European customers and can provide specific geographic information for data storage locations. Data location documentation is available through AWS regional specifications, and we can provide data residency certificates upon request.

Question Text: Can you provide the physical location/geography of storage of a tenant's data in advance?
Comment: Our service deployment process enables advance specification of data storage locations based on customer requirements and compliance needs. This would be documented in customer service agreements with clear geographic boundaries.

Question Text: Do you allow tenants to define acceptable geographical locations for data routing or resource instantiation?\n\nIf Bayer requests this, is it a possibility?
Comment: IBP can accommodate customer-specific geographic requirements through AWS regional services and deployment configurations. For Bayer, we can implement geographic restrictions to ensure data processing remains within specified regions through appropriate AWS configuration.

Question Text: Are systems in place to monitor for privacy breaches and notify tenants expeditiously if a privacy event may have impacted their data?\n\nHow quickly are tenants notified?
Comment: Our Data Protection Policy establishes privacy breach detection using AWS GuardDuty, CloudTrail, and monitoring systems. We target rapid customer notification for confirmed privacy breaches, with the goal of notification within 4 hours, formalized through customer service agreements.

Question Text: Do you allow tenants to opt out of having their data/metadata accessed via inspection technologies?\n\nPlease describe this process If metadata is collected, what type of data is it and how is it used?
Comment: While our Data Protection Policy addresses metadata handling, we do not currently have comprehensive opt-out mechanisms for inspection technologies. Basic metadata (access logs, performance metrics) is collected for security and operational purposes. Customer opt-out capabilities would be developed for enterprise requirements.

Question Text: Do you provide the client with a list and copies of all subprocessing agreements and keep this updated?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy requires maintenance of subprocessor documentation. We can provide customers with lists of subprocessors and relevant agreement information (under confidentiality provisions) with updates for material changes to subprocessing arrangements.

Question Text: Do you review the risk management and governance processes of partners to account for risks inherited from other members of that partner's supply chain?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy includes supply chain risk assessment requirements for critical vendors, including review of subcontractor management practices and disclosure of material subprocessing arrangements with documented risk treatment.

Question Text: Are policies and procedures established, and supporting business processes and technical measures implemented, for maintaining complete, accurate, and relevant agreements (e.g., SLAs) between providers and customers (tenants)?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy establishes SLA management procedures, though comprehensive customer SLA frameworks would be developed as part of formal service agreements. We maintain contract management processes with regular reviews and performance tracking capabilities.

Question Text: Do you have the ability to measure and address non-conformance of provisions and/or terms across the entire supply chain (upstream/downstream)?
Comment: While our Vendor Management Policy includes vendor performance monitoring procedures, we do not currently have comprehensive supply chain non-conformance measurement capabilities across upstream/downstream relationships. This would be enhanced for enterprise customer requirements.

Question Text: Can you manage service-level conflicts or inconsistencies resulting from disparate supplier relationships?
Comment: Given our organizational size and current vendor relationship scope, we have limited capabilities for managing complex service-level conflicts across disparate suppliers. This capability would be developed as our vendor ecosystem expands with enterprise customers.

Question Text: Do you provide tenants with ongoing visibility and reporting of your operational Service Level Agreement (SLA) performance?
Comment: While we maintain internal performance monitoring through AWS tools, we do not currently provide formal SLA performance reporting to customers. This capability would be developed as part of enterprise service agreements with customers like Bayer.

Question Text: Do you make standards-based information security metrics (CSA, CAMM, etc.) available to your tenants?\n\nIf yes, please specify which metrics
Comment: While we maintain security metrics internally and can complete assessments like this CAIQ, we do not currently provide formal standards-based security metrics to customers. We could develop CSA-aligned reporting capabilities for enterprise customer requirements.

Question Text: Do you provide customers with ongoing visibility and reporting of your SLA performance?
Comment: We do not currently provide formal SLA performance reporting to customers, though we maintain internal performance monitoring. Regular SLA reporting would be developed as part of enterprise customer service agreements.

Question Text: Do your data management policies and procedures address tenant and service level conflicts of interests?
Comment: Our Data Protection Policy and Access Control Policy establish clear data segregation and tenant isolation procedures preventing conflicts of interest through strict data separation and independent access controls for each customer.

Question Text: Do you review all service level agreements at least annually?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy mandates annual review of service agreements including performance assessment and terms validation. Customer service agreements would follow similar annual review processes.

Question Text: Do you assure reasonable information security across your information supply chain by performing an annual review?\n\nDo you have any contractual obligations with providers to ensure security requirements are met?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy requires annual security reviews for all critical vendors and establishes contractual security obligations including compliance with security standards and incident notification requirements for all vendors handling customer data.

Question Text: Does your annual review include all partners/third-party providers upon which your information supply chain depends?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy establishes comprehensive vendor management covering all third-party providers in our supply chain including critical vendors, standard vendors, and subprocessors with risk-based assessment procedures.

Question Text: Do you mandate annual information security reviews and audits of your third party providers to ensure that all agreed upon security requirements are met?\n\nPlease describe this process
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy establishes annual security reviews for critical vendors including security questionnaires, SOC 2 report reviews, and compliance verification. We maintain vendor security assessments with documented findings and corrective action tracking.

Question Text: Do you have external third party services conduct vulnerability scans and periodic penetration tests on your applications and networks?\n\nWhat tools are used? Can you provide results?
Comment: While we utilize AWS native security scanning and have comprehensive internal vulnerability management procedures, we do not currently conduct external third-party penetration testing. We plan to implement external security assessments and can accommodate this requirement for enterprise customers.

Question Text: Do you have anti-malware programs that support or connect to your cloud service offerings installed on all of your IT infrastructure network and systems components?\n\nWhat tools are used?
Comment: Our security framework includes AWS GuardDuty for cloud-native threat detection and our Remote Work Security Policy requires anti-malware software on all devices. We utilize AWS security services and endpoint protection, though comprehensive anti-malware deployment across all infrastructure components is ongoing.

Question Text: Do you ensure that security threat detection systems using signatures, lists, or behavioral patterns are updated across all infrastructure components as prescribed by industry best practices?\n\nWhat tools are used?
Comment: Our threat detection utilizes AWS GuardDuty with automatic threat intelligence updates, CloudWatch for behavioral monitoring, and AWS Config for compliance monitoring. Security systems receive automatic updates, though comprehensive coverage across all infrastructure components is progressive.

Question Text: Do you conduct network-layer vulnerability scans regularly as prescribed by industry best practices?
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy includes vulnerability management using AWS Inspector and network security assessments. We conduct regular vulnerability scanning of network infrastructure with documented response procedures, though scan frequency is optimized for our organizational scale.

Question Text: Do you conduct application-layer vulnerability scans regularly as prescribed by industry best practices?
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy includes application security scanning integrated into our development processes using static analysis and dependency scanning. We conduct regular application vulnerability assessments with defined remediation requirements for identified issues.

Question Text: Do you conduct local operating system-layer vulnerability scans regularly as prescribed by industry best practices?
Comment: We utilize AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager for operating system vulnerability management and patching. We conduct regular OS vulnerability scanning with automated patching capabilities and vulnerability tracking with defined response timeframes.

Question Text: Will you make the results of vulnerability scans available to tenants at their request?
Comment: Our policies support transparency with customers regarding security assessments. We can provide vulnerability scan summaries and security assessment results to customers under appropriate confidentiality agreements, with customer-specific risk assessments available.

Question Text: Do you have a capability to patch vulnerabilities across all of your computing devices, applications, and systems?\n\nPlease specify your patching timeframes for Critical/High/Medium findings.
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy establishes patch management using AWS Systems Manager with defined timeframes: Critical (24 hours), High (72 hours), Medium (7 days). We maintain automated patching capabilities with testing and rollback procedures.

Question Text: Do you inform customers (tenant) of policies and procedures and identified weaknesses if customer (tenant) data is used as part the service and/or customer (tenant) has some shared responsibility over implementation of control?
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy follows the AWS shared responsibility model and we provide customers with documentation of security policies and shared responsibilities. We communicate security findings that require customer awareness through appropriate channels.

Question Text: Is mobile code authorized before its installation and use, and the code configuration checked, to ensure that the authorized mobile code operates according to a clearly defined security policy?
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy establishes code security requirements including review procedures and security validation. All code deployments require security review and compliance verification before production deployment through documented approval processes.

Question Text: Is all unauthorized mobile code prevented from executing?
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy includes application security controls and deployment restrictions. We utilize AWS security controls and access restrictions to prevent unauthorized code execution with monitoring for non-approved execution attempts.
